title: Investigating the Relationship Between Air Quality and Cancer Incidence in the United States
text:
1 Introduction
Title: Investigating the Relationship Between Air Quality and Cancer Incidence in the United States
Why Choose This Topic:

Public Health Impact: Cancer is a leading cause of death globally, and its incidence is on the rise. Investigating the relationship between cancer and air quality can provide insights into environmental factors contributing to cancer risk.
Environmental Concerns: Air quality affects the health of millions of people. Poor air quality, characterized by pollutants like particulate matter (PM) has been associated with various health problems, including respiratory and cardiovascular diseases.
Policy Implications: Understanding the link between air quality and cancer can inform evidence-based policies and regulations aimed at reducing cancer rates by improving air quality. This research can contribute to more effective public health strategies.

Questions we are interested in studying:

Whether certain cancer subtypes (e.g., lung cancer, bladder cancer) show a stronger association with poor air quality? Whether certain states have higher rate of certain cancer subtypes?
Determine if there are geographical areas in the United States with consistently poor air quality and elevated cancer rates. Are there particular pollutants associated with these areas?
Whether there is a statistically significant correlation between long-term exposure to poor air quality (measured by pollutants like PM2.5, ozone, and VOCs) and the incidence of specific cancer types in different regions of the United States?

Context About the Measurement of Air Quality:
We would assess air quality using various measurements, including:

Daily Ozone Concentrations Daily ozone concentrations refer to the levels of ozone (O3) gas in the atmosphere measured on a daily basis. Ozone is a reactive gas composed of three oxygen atoms (O3), and it is a key component of Earth’s atmosphere. While ozone high in the stratosphere (stratospheric ozone) plays a crucial role in protecting us from harmful ultraviolet (UV) radiation from the sun, ozone at ground level (tropospheric ozone) is an air pollutant that can have health and environmental impacts.
Daily PM2.5 Concentrations Daily PM2.5 concentrations refer to the levels of fine particulate matter (PM2.5) in the air measured on a daily basis. PM2.5 refers to tiny airborne particles or aerosols with a diameter of 2.5 micrometers or smaller. These particles are so small that they can be inhaled deeply into the lungs and even enter the bloodstream, posing health risks to humans.

title: 2  Data
text:
2.1 Research plan

To answer what geographical areas in the United States have consistently poor air quality. We would perform time series analysis and draw time series line plot. Also, we will use box plot to get a summary of air quality data for multiple regions in a compact format. Each box plot represents a region, and the boxes display the distribution of air quality values (e.g., median, quartiles). Regions with consistently poor air quality will have lower medians and wider interquartile ranges. To double check our finding, we would use heatmap to visualize air quality data across both time and regions. Rows represent regions, columns represent time intervals, and the color scale indicates air quality levels. Consistently poor air quality regions will be represented by darker colors on the heatmap.
After knowing what geographical areas have poor air quality, we need to answer questions about whether certain states have a higher rate of specific cancer subtypes and then explore whether certain cancer subtypes show a stronger association with poor air quality. We will first draw bar charts to compare cancer incidence rates for different cancer subtypes across states. Each subtype can be represented by a different color, and states can be grouped along the x-axis. As we have a large dataset about cancer incidence, we will need interactive plots to provide additional insights and allow us to zoom in on specific data points. We would also draw time series line plot to explore the trend of cancer incidence and compare with the line we got for air condition.
Finally to answer whether there is a statistically significant correlation between long-term exposure to poor air quality, we will first draw scatter plots can show the relationship between two continuous variables cancer incidence rates and air quality levels. And then, we will perform hypothesis testing using Pearson’s test and get a conclusion based on p-value.

title: 2  Data
text:
2.2 Missing value analysis
Load required libraries


Code
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(reshape2)
library(tidyverse)
library(mi)
library(redav)


For the cancer dataset, from the description of the website, all missing and null values are shown as “Missing” in the dataset. Here I convert all “Missing” values to NA and show them in graph.


Code
data <- data %>%
  mutate(across(where(is.character), ~na_if(., "Missing")))




Code
colSums(is.na(data))


     Leading.Cancer.Sites Leading.Cancer.Sites.Code                    States 
                        0                         0                         0 
              States.Code                      Year                 Year.Code 
                        0                         0                         0 
                      Sex                  Sex.Code                     Count 
                        0                         0                        12 
               Population                Crude Rate 
                       12                        12 


It seems like the number of null values in the cancer data frame is not large. Here we want to find which rows contains the null values.


Code
# Get the row indices that have any NA values
na_rows <- which(apply(is.na(data), 1, any), arr.ind=TRUE)
selected_rows <- data[na_rows, ]
selected_rows

1479        Kidney and Renal Pelvis                     29020 Mississippi

3352              Lung and Bronchus                     22030 Mississippi

4370           Melanoma of the Skin                     25010 Mississippi

5385        Oral Cavity and Pharynx               20010-20100 Mississippi

From the graph we find that all values of count, population and crude rate in 2002 and Mississippi are missing.


Code
x <- missing_data.frame(data)


NOTE: The following pairs of variables appear to have the same missingness pattern.
 Please verify whether they are in fact logically distinct variables.
     [,1]         [,2]        
[1,] "Count"      "Population"
[2,] "Count"      "Crude Rate"
[3,] "Population" "Crude Rate"


Warning in .local(.Object, ...): States and States.Code have the same rank ordering.
 Please verify whether they are in fact distinct variables.


Warning in .local(.Object, ...): Year and Year.Code have the same rank ordering.
 Please verify whether they are in fact distinct variables.


Warning in .local(.Object, ...): Sex and Sex.Code have the same rank ordering.
 Please verify whether they are in fact distinct variables.


Code
image(x)







Code
plot_missing(data, percent = FALSE)





Code
levels(x@patterns)


[1] "nothing"                       "Count, Population, Crude.Rate"


Code
summary(x@patterns)


                      nothing Count, Population, Crude.Rate 
                         5906                            12 


From the graph we can see that only columns of count, population, and crude rate have missing values. And all missing values are from the state of Mississipi during the year of 2002.
For the PM2.5 Concentrations dataset:


Code
colSums(is.na (pm) ) |> sort(decreasing = TRUE)


             year         statefips max_pm25_max_pred avg_pm25_pop_pred 
                0                 0                 0                 0 




Code
plot_missing(pm, percent = FALSE)





Based on the missing pattern graph and the NA count in the dataset, there is no missing values.
For the Ozone Concentrations dataset:


Code
colSums(is.na (ozone) ) |> sort(decreasing = TRUE)


          year2       statefips max_o3_max_pred avg_o3_pop_pred 
              0               0               0               0 




Code
plot_missing(ozone, percent = FALSE)





Based on the missing pattern graph and the NA count in the dataset, there is no missing values.
